oai_dc:dc.dc:title: NEAR-SURFACE ORBITAL VELOCITIES IN IRREGULAR WAVES
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Daemrich, K.-F.
Gotschenberg, A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: irregular wave
orbital velocity
near surface velocity
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The paper deals with measurements of horizontal orbital velocities near the surface of mechanically generated waves in a wave flume. Due to the characteristics of most velocity probes, it is difficult or impossible to measure with a fixed probe in the area above the lowest trough. As the probe is not submerged continuously, failures or uncertainties in the measurements may occur. To overcome these limitations, a movable frame for the velocity probe was designed, which can be moved vertically up and down with the surface elevation by a disc rotor servo motor, controlled by a wave gauge. By that continuously velocities up to 3 cm below the surface could be measured. Theoretical velocities have been calculated for comparison with different simulation methods for irregular waves, based on linear wave theory.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 20 (1986): Proceedings of 20th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Taipei, Taiwan, 1986.; 8
